a.title: Remote Learning Update from Superintendent Jacqueline Coe

h2.a: Remote Learning Update from Superintendent Jacqueline Coe

section.p: April 16, 2020

This afternoon, Governor Sununu announced the extension of the school closure and the continuation of remote learning through the end of the academic year. He noted that the decision was necessary because we are not able to bring students back into the school buildings in a way that doesnt exacerbate the spread of coronavirus. He expressed gratitude for the way that New Hampshires community of educators, students, and families have come together during this difficult time.
This new phase of remote learning brings about more questions and additional logistics to figure out. Below are details on some of the topics that we anticipate you may have questions about.

Remote Learning and WIN Days
Remote learning will continue through June 12 for the John Stark, Henniker, and Weare School Districts.

One recent change we implemented inK-8 in the Henniker and WeareSchool Districts is WIN. WIN (What I Need) Days were added in response to the overwhelmed feeling expressed by many parents, students, and teachers. Many parents are trying to juggle supporting their childrens remote learning with their own work responsibilities. Some students are finding that they need additional time and support to complete assignments. Additionally, educators are trying to fit their professional responsibilities around meeting the needs of students. WIN days allow for the flexibility to meet some of these needs and to ease some of the strain our community is feeling. It will help us to build capacity in order to sustain remote learning through the long term.

On WIN Days, students will do a brief morning check-in with their teacher to share their plan for the day. While it is not a day for new learning, students will have the option to do make-up work, engage in extension activities, work with interventionists, and take advantage of other offerings during a WIN Day. Teachers will use the remainder of the day to address the long list of responsibilities, including communicating with parents and students, collaborating with colleagues, preparing instructional materials, and engaging students requiring individualized support.

p.strong: April Vacation and the Last Day of School

li.p: Monday, 4/27 and Tuesday, 4/28 will be vacation days for students and staff.
Remote learning will continue for the remainder of that week (Wednesday-Friday).
There will NOT be a WIN day that week.
The last day of school for students will be June 12 in the John Stark, Henniker and Weare districts

section.p:
Grading & Reporting
Teachers will continue to report out on student progress and grading will continue as it did pre-remote learning, but fewer standards and less content will be addressed than in a typical spring term. New Hampshire students will not take NHSAS, SAT, and DLM testing this spring. The possibility of issuing vouchers to high school students who may wish to take the SAT in early June (if it is available at that time) is being explored.

Summer Educational Programming
If state officials allow, we have plans to offer summer programming for students. The offerings will include special education and related services, remediation, and enrichment. We are making plans with the understanding that there may still be restrictions through the summer. If we are not able to bring students back into the schools, we are exploring possible virtual options for supporting and engaging students in July and August.

End-of-Year Celebrations & Ceremonies
At every grade level, there are end-of-year celebrations that occur. These events highlight achievements, build community, and bring closure to the school year. It is impossible to make definite plans right now, but we do have tentative plans for BIG TENT WEEK from August 2-8. In addition to graduation, we are proposing that prom, 8th-grade promotion, field day, and other significant events happen during that week. If it is safe to do so, this will be a nice opportunity to bring the community together.

Budget
The worldwide crisis is causing significant economic uncertainty. While we will continue to pay people, maintain the buildings, and do necessary work on the buildings, we will avoid all non-essential spending across the SAU. We are also in the process of looking at how best to use grant money that we anticipate receiving through the federal Coronavirus Care Fund.

Student Services
Ensuring that students with disabilities are not left behind during this epidemic has been a major priority. We have taken a number of steps to make sure that all students are getting access to the education they are entitled to receive. Over 1500 specialized services are currently being provided remotely through our Special Education & ELL programs. We are tracking whether students are meeting their annual IEP goals and are receiving all of the special education and related services articulated in their IEP. Extended school year services will be offered to students who need them, as determined by individual IEP teams. ESY services will be provided in person (if allowable) or through remote learning (if needed). Check with your childs case manager for specific dates and times.

Meal Delivery
The USDA and the State of NH have approved a waiver that allows schools to offer meals to all students 18 and under free of charge. These meals will be delivered weekdays to your home address. This is only for the duration of the current COVID-19 crisis and will not expand into the summer break. If you have not been receiving meals during this crisis and want breakfast and lunch to be delivered, contact:

li.p: Weare School District: 603-529-8012

section.p: If your household income has been affected due to this current crisis, you may wish to fill out a free or reduced application to see if you are eligible for free or reduced pricing when school resumes. An approved application now would be in effect until October 2020. Applications are available on the school websites.

Board Meetings
Due to concerns surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic, the school boards in SAU 24 will continue to hold all business meetings and special sessions online. All board meetings will remain open to the public. We encourage our community members to join us and make your voices heard during the public comment portion of the meetings. Information about upcoming board meetings on the school websites.

School Contacts
If you have specific questions or concerns about remote learning or future plans, please contact the building principal.

To view a video of this message:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FksURwSSs0M
or read the transcript below.

div.p:
April 11, 2020 Update
The Governors March 15 closure of schools and shift to remote learning set off a whirlwind of activity. Our teachers, staff, and administrators created, and continue to create, meaningful ways to connect with students. We set out with the mantra, connect with each student, each school day. Through flexibility, dedication, and ingenuity, we have met this target. I am most proud to announce that we have indeed connected with each child and that our attendance rates for remote learning continue to be high.

I have loved seeing the great photos and videos of students and teachers engaged in remote learning. We are working with our parents to balance virtual connection with developmentally appropriate limits on screen time. Our families are not the only ones working to find balance. Our staff members are learning to establish the boundaries necessary to meet both the needs of their students and those of their own families.

Last week, we conducted surveys of our parents, staff, and grade 6-12 students to inform how we move forward with remote learning. Over 750 parents and almost 200 staff members responded. Additionally, over 600 students participated in the survey. I will go over some of the results before sharing next steps.

li.p: When asked to give an overall rating for remote learning so far, about 60% of parents reported a positive rating (4 or 5) for remote learning. About 10% reported a negative (1 or 2) rating.

About 32% of the grade 6-12 students who responded reported a positive rating (4 or 5) for remote learning. About 40% had a neutral rating. Our Juniors and Seniors gave the lowest rating. The vast majority of students reported spending between 2-6 hours
47% of our faculty and staff gave a positive rating for remote learning.
When parents were asked about the quantity and quality of the work assigned to their child, about 70% said that it was effective.

div.p: We also asked what people were concerned about.

li.p: About 30% of parents were quite concerned about their childs learning during remote instruction, about their childs social/emotional wellbeing, and about screen time.
Over 50% of parents reported concern about their familys health.
Around 15% had concerns around food, physical well-being, childcare and technology access.

The majority (over 60%) of the faculty and staff who responded noted that they were concerned or extremely concerned about meeting the individual needs of students, about their students social/emotional wellbeing, and screen time

div.p: These are some highlights. The Leadership Team and teachers spent quite a bit of time this past week digging into the survey feedback. Our overall takeaways include:

li.p: Overall, SAU 24 did a good job transitioning to remote learning.
We are grateful for the technology and other infrastructure that was in place that made the relatively smooth transition possible.
The responsiveness of our teachers and staff to individual student needs is appreciated by the community.
The daily check-ins provided through morning meetings, homeroom and advisory are valuable.
Flexibility and choice are essential.
There is concern about our ability to sustain this effort long-term.
Structures and guidelines are needed as we move into a long-term closure.
We continue to have concern that some students are falling further behind

div.p: When we began this journey almost a month ago, we were responding to a short term crisis. We are now approaching the end of our fourth week in remote learning. Moving forward, we are putting structures in place that allow for a long-term implementation in response to community concerns and issues.

Grading
One of the first issues we need to address is grading. Teachers will continue to report out on student progress and grading will continue as it did pre-remote learning, but classes will address few standards and less content than in a typical spring term.

The school closure has offered us the opportunity to streamline and simplify the pursuit of what really matters in teaching and learning. Teachers are not being asked to water down content, offer less meaningful lessons, or permit students to skate by on low standards. Rather, teachers are being asked to focus on the skills and knowledge that will endure after the course.

We have come to understand that flexibility is essential. Families are navigating many different kinds of challenges. For some, the structure of remote learning helps to make the stay-at-home order experience manageable. For others, the expectations of remote learning add to the stress that they are already managing. We continue to design developmentally appropriate lessons that blend virtual activities with hands-ones and synchronous work with asynchronous work.

K-8 Henniker and Weare - WIN (What I Need) Days
WIN was developed in response to the overwhelmed feeling expressed by many parents, students, and teachers. Educators are trying to fit their professional responsibilities around meeting the needs of students. Many parents are trying to juggle supporting their childrens remote learning with their own work responsibilities. Some students are finding that they need additional time and support to complete assignments. The addition of WIN days allows for the flexibility to meet some of the needs and to ease some of the strain our community is feeling. It will help us to build capacity in order to sustain remote learning through the long term.

John Stark Regional High School adopted Digital Mondays early on in our remote learning journey. We are now adapting this practice K-8 in Henniker and Weare through WIN (or What I Need). Most weeks, WIN will happen on Wednesday, beginning on April 15.

On WIN Days, students will do a brief morning check-in with their teacher to share their plan for the day. While it is not a day for new learning, students will have the option to do make-up work, engage in extension activities, work with interventionists, and take advantage of other offerings. Teachers will use the remainder of the day to address a long list of responsibilities, including communicating with parents and students, collaborating with colleagues, preparing instructional materials, and engaging students requiring individualized support.

April Vacation
I want to share my thinking around April Vacation. I anticipate that this will be much like many snow day decisions and that not everyone will be satisfied.

As I announced in my message on April 2, based on the current May 4 return-to-school date, we are keeping April Vacation as scheduled. The last day of school will be June 18. There will be two teacher work days before any return to school.

Should the Governor extend the school closure, then Monday, 4/27 and Tuesday, 4/28 will be vacation days for students and staff. Remote learning will continue for the remainder of that week and the last day of school for everyone will be June 12.
This decision is an effort to meet the need for a break expressed by many with the desire to maintain the rhythm we have begun to develop with remote learning.

Blood Donation
Lastly, The American Red Cross approached me to ask you to please consider donating blood as we are facing a severe blood shortage. Please check out the Red Cross website for more details.https://www.redcross.org/local/new-hampshire-vermont.html

a.title: Free Meals for All Under the Age of 18Beginning April 6, 2020, in SAU 24

h2.a: Free Meals for All Under the Age of 18Beginning April 6, 2020, in SAU 24

section.p: Reminder: There is no school on April 6, as is a Teacher Day, however, meals will be delivered.

The USDA and the State of NH have approved a waiver that allows schools to offer meals to all students 18 and under free of charge. These meals will be delivered on weekdays to your home address. This is only for the duration of the current COVID-19 crisis and will not expand into the summer break.
WHAT DO I NEED TO DO?

li.p: If you have been receiving meals, but paying for them, you do not need to do anything. You will continue to receive meals, but you will not be charged.
If you have been receiving free or reduced meals, you do not need to do anything. You will continue to receive meals and you will not be charged.

section.p: Additional Information

li.p: Delivery times may change due to the increase in potential deliveries.
If your child does NOT attend an SAU 24 school, they are still eligible to receive free meals. Please call the number listed below.

section.p: If your household income has been affected due to this current crisis, you may wish to fill out a free or reduced application to see if you are eligible for free or reduced pricing when school resumes. An approved application now would be in effect until October 2020. Applications are available on the school website or we can send one home with your students meals next week.
If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to call.
Thank you and stay safe.

a.title: Food Service Information for JSRHS as of 3/23/2020

h2.a: Food Service Information for JSRHS as of 3/23/2020

p.span: As you are aware, SAU24 and John Stark Regional High School are closed due to COVID-19.
The closure will run at least through April 3, 2020. Despite this closure, we are committed to continuing to provide quality learning opportunities to our students. To do so, we will be implementing
online learning beginning on
Until further notice, the building is closed to all staff and students. Only essential staff will be allowed in the building. If you need to reach a staff member, you will need to do so by email.
to access the staff email directory.

Our online remote learning will be facilitated through Google Classroom. Teachers will attempt to be available from 9:00am until 1:00pm each day, but may post alternate times within their Google Classroom. Teachers will generally respond to emails within 24 hours; however, please understand that personal situations may impact their ability to do so.
CLICK HERE to go the the Digital Learning Technology Support for Families Page.
Advisory-based Digital Learning Mondays (see reference below); Students will receive an email from their Advisor and should respond. The resources for

a.span: Digital Learning Mondays may be found at this link

p.span: A Days Course-Specific Activity; Students will receive an email from their Advisor and should respond
B Days Course-Specific Activity; Students will receive an email from their Advisor and should respond
This plan will be in place until at least April 3rd. If the closure continues, we will also continue with this same plan.
All teachers are committed to thoughtfully planning learning activities for our students. These activities will be related to course competencies with the goal of moving learning forward.
Clarity and consistency of communication is essential for the comfort and success of all. All stakeholders should adhere to the following guidelines for the duration of this adventure:

li.span: Advisors will check in, via email, with the students in their advisory every day. Students should reply to the daily email.
Classroom teachers may post work the morning of a specific class or may post the work for the entire week beginning on Monday.
Students are expected to complete all assignments and contact their teacher if additional support is needed.
Students will be using the
website to guide their learning on Mondays during the extended school closure. Directions are provided on the website.
Accountability for all specific courses will be handled by individual classroom teachers and those related assignments and activities.
PowerSchool will be up-to-date for grades.

p.span: While School Counseling is best done in person, we have systems in place to support students remotely.

li.span: You can access our current
by navigating the School Counseling website. A few have been highlighted below.
You can
to your counselor or Dr. Zielinski or Mrs. Getman via email and expect a response within 24 hours.
Counselors will respond to concerns regarding
can be sent to Mrs. Glynn, who will respond within 48 hours. Please plan accordingly.
If you still need to schedule your
, please email your counselor.
Transcript requests may be made via
Email signed request to
This email address is being protected from spambots. You need JavaScript enabled to view it.
Education Verifications can be sent to
This email address is being protected from spambots. You need JavaScript enabled to view it.

p.span: The Health Office would like to offer our support during this time of uncertainty. Please feel free to contact us regarding any health/medication concerns and health updates especially when the time nears to return to school. Our school nurse, Susan Kizler (
This email address is being protected from spambots. You need JavaScript enabled to view it.
) will be checking email frequently.
You will still be able to email or fax us any physicals, immunizations or other health related paperwork/MD notes.
A separate email from our office will include more detailed information.
As this situation unfolds, we will continue to provide updated information as it pertains to student learning. Thank you for partnering with us as we work through these challenging times.
Regards,
The John Stark Administration, Faculty and Staff

a.title: JSRHS Art Students Selected for NH Art Educators Annual Youth Art Month Exhibit

h2.a: JSRHS Art Students Selected for NH Art Educators Annual Youth Art Month Exhibit

p.span: Eight John Stark Regional High School art students have been invited to participate in the New Hampshire Art Educators Annual Youth Art Month (YAM) Exhibit at the NH State Library in Concord through March 22. The library is open Monday
through Friday from 8-4:30 PM. The public is also invited to the exhibition reception on Sunday, March 22 from 1-3 PM. The NH State Library is located at 20 Park Street, across from the State House.

JSRHS students in this exhibition include Lauren Zervos, who has been selected to receive the YAM 2020 Commissioners Award for her Looking into the Distance (Charcoal), Eli Bryant, Love in Ruins (Charcoal), Summer Clement, Saddie (Oil Pastel), Stephanie Rodonis, Visible (Digital Photography), Maddie Dionne, Great Bay (Printmaking with Watercolor), Lydia Piscina, Jungle (Acrylic & Resin), Sheridan OBrien, Roaring 20s (Scanography Photograph), and Gracie Bolduc, Sassy Pants (Watercolor).

The students in this exhibit havedemonstrated rigor in the classroom, commitment to mastering the skills taught in class, and have worked to push creative boundaries, said JSRHS teacher Tracy Travers. Theyve developed an artistic voice and are using their art as a way to educate and communicate, she continued.
John Stark senior Lauren Zervos will be presented with the 2020 Commissioners Award at the exhibit reception on March 22.

section.p: Image 1:Looking into the Distance, charcoal by Lauren Zervos. Lauren earned the 2020 YAM Commissioners' Award for this piece.
Image 2:Saddie, oil pastel by junior Summer Clement
section.div: Image 3:Visible(digital photography) by junior Stephanie Rodonis as displayed at the NH Art Educator'sYouth Art Month Exhibit.
Image 4:Roaring 20s(scanography photograph) by junior Sheridan O' Brien.

a.title: JSRHS student qualifies to take invitational math exam

h2.a: JSRHS student qualifies to take invitational math exam

div.span: John Stark Regional High School Junior Nathan Chasse has qualified for the American Invitational Mathematics Exam (AIME) based on his performance in the American Mathematics Competition. To qualify for the AIME, Nathan needed to score in the top 5% in the American Mathematics Competition. Nathan will take theAmerican Invitational Mathematics Examination in mid-March. The exam isa 15-question, 3-hour test and the use of calculators is not allowed.Concepts typically covered on the AIME include topics in elementary algebra, geometry, trigonometry, as well as number theory, probability, and combinatorics.

span.span: The AIME is also used to determine qualification for the United States Mathematical Olympiad.

a.title: JSRHS Senior Jillian LaBrecque takes Capstone Project to Theatre Festival, March 7

h2.a: JSRHS Senior Jillian LaBrecque takes Capstone Project to Theatre Festival, March 7

p.span: John Stark senior Jillian LaBrecque directed the one-act playThe Other Roomwith the John Stark Stage Company as her senior capstone project, a graduation requirement, last fall. She has since decided to take the play and her work a step beyond her project and present it at the New Hampshire Educators Theatre Guilds Regional Festival (NHEGT) at Concord High School on March 7.

Why go so far above and beyond the original scope of her capstone project, especially given its her senior year that has kept her busy with school work, participating in NH Jazz All-State, applying for college, and being cast in the schools spring production, 'Legally Blond'? I have always loved the festival experience. Its the best a high school theatre student can have, said Jillian, who was part of the cast and crew who took John Starks production ofSense and Sensibilityto the festival last year. When our theatre teacher Mrs. Matzke asked if Id like to take my project to the festival, I jumped at the chance and had her sign me up right away. While there will be a few student-directed plays at this regional festival, most are being directed by adults.

Ms. LaBrecque was also motived to take her capstone project above and beyond because of the nature and message ofThe Other Room. I wanted to share it with an even bigger audience, she said about the play, written by Ariadne Blayde, that tells the story of a brilliant student astronomer who has autism and a popular girl in his school who also likes astronomy. The story tells of the boys struggle to connect with the world and her desire to better understand him.

Jillian plans to head to college in the fall and while she hasnt made her final decision as to where shell attend at the moment, she thinks shell end up as an education major and eventually teach. My experience at John Stark has been great and shown me how many teachers will go the extra mile to help you accomplish whatever you want to do. Weekends, nights, after school, theyll help you and I like that, she said.

About to head off to class, Jillian had one more comment to make about her experience at John Stark. If youre driven, you can do whatever you want to do at John Stark. Theres always someone to help you achieve your goals and dreams, concluded Ms. LaBreque.
For tickets and information to the NHETG theatre festival in Concord, please visit:https://sites.google.com/view/new-nhetg/
